qas.question: What did the Greeks offer to the Ottoman Empire that was a superb benefit ?

answers.text: the Greek tradition of education and commerce

qas.question: Who held much of the wealth in the Greek society ?

answers.text: the wealth of the extensive merchant class

qas.question: What three cities were imperative for the scholarly and economic exchanges ?

answers.text: the three most important centres of Greek learning were situated in Chios, Smyrna and Aivali, all three major centres of Greek commerce

qas.question: What other area fields were overshadowed by Greek influence ?

answers.text: Greek domination of the Christian Orthodox church.

qas.question: What did the Greeks offer to the Ottoman Empire that wasn't a superb benefit ?
Who held none of the wealth in the Greek society?
What three cities were not imperative for the scholarly and economic exchanges

plausible_answers.text: Greek domination of the Christian Orthodox church

qas.question: What other area fields were not overshadowed by Greek influence?

context: The roots of Greek success in the Ottoman Empire can be traced to <a0_0>the Greek <b4_0>tradition of education and commerce<b4_0/><a0_0/>. It was <a1_0>the wealth of the <b5_0>extensive merchant class<b5_0/><a1_0/> that provided the material basis for the intellectual revival that was the prominent feature of Greek life in the half century and more leading to the outbreak of the Greek War of Independence in 1821. Not coincidentally, on the eve of 1821, <a2_0>the three most important centres of Greek learning were situated in <b6_0>Chios, Smyrna and Aivali<b6_0/>, all three major centres of Greek commerce<a2_0/>. Greek success was also favoured by <a3_0><b7_0>Greek domination of the Christian Orthodox church<b7_0/>.
